Award.AwardTitle: The quantitative landscape of the mitotic checkpoint: from genes to function

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Regulation of the cell cycle is critical for the growth and development of all organisms and the information needed to control this process is encoded in the DNA of the genome. The genome not only specifies which biomolecules are being produced, but also specifies their quantities, which is important since too little or too much of a biomolecule can lead to cellular malfunction. Despite this importance, it is still incompletely understood how the information regulating levels of biomolecules is specified in the genome sequence. This project will examine one particular regulatory pathway, the "mitotic checkpoint", which controls the inheritance of chromosomes during cellular division. This pathway only functions properly if the proteins that make up the pathway are present at the optimal concentrations. By combining laboratory experiments and computational analyses, this project will identify critical regions on the genome that control the quantity of proteins in the mitotic checkpoint and thereby control checkpoint function. This research will enhance our ability to interpret and purposefully modify genome sequences, with benefits for gene technology and synthetic biology. Furthermore, the project will provide training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students that prepare them for careers in biotechnology or basic research and enhance their skills to work at the interface of traditional disciplines.

Critical transitions in the eukaryotic cell cycle are guarded by checkpoints. The mitotic checkpoint prevents the precocious separation of duplicated chromosomes and thereby protects genome integrity. To function properly, the mitotic checkpoint needs precise concentrations of the proteins that act in this signaling pathway. Yet, hardly anything is known about how transcription and translation of the checkpoint genes is quantitatively controlled to yield these levels. This work will determine how checkpoint protein levels are kept within their permissive range and why checkpoint functionality is restricted to this range. Cas9-mediated genome engineering in fission yeast will be used to map the genetic regions that are critical to control checkpoint protein levels. This experimental analysis will be complemented by a bioinformatic analysis of these genes. Checkpoint functionality assays will be used to address how different checkpoint protein levels affect the activity and critical dynamics of the checkpoint. These results will be combined into a predictive computational model for checkpoint activity that will shed light on how this checkpoint operates. Overall, this project will provide new insights into the dynamics of checkpoint signaling and into the relation between genotype, quantitative gene expression control and phenotype.

POR.DRECONTENT:
When cells divide, they need to accurately distribute their genetic information to the two daughter cells. Any errors can lead to cell death, or can provoke further errors and eventually lead to cancerous growth. In eukaryotes (e.g. humans, plants, or yeast), the duplication and distribution of the genome is protected by checkpoints. These checkpoints are cellular signaling pathways that make sure that all prior steps have been successfully completed before proceeding to the next step. The mitotic checkpoint is one such pathway and is crucial to protect cells from mis-segregating their chromosomes. We and others have found that optimal functioning of this checkpoint requires that cells produce just the right amount of checkpoint proteins; having either too little or too much can impair the checkpoint. Yet hardly anything was known about how cells control which amount of these proteins is produced. To start to understand this, we have identified genetic regions in fission yeast that control the expression of mitotic checkpoint genes and have characterized the features of these regions. We have found that, in addition to non-coding regions, the protein-coding regions of mitotic checkpoint genes influence their expression. These results have revealed unexpected aspects of gene expression and shed light on how mutations in or around the checkpoint genes may impair the function of the checkpoint. In particular, our results suggest that mutations within the coding region that do not change the amino acid sequence may still affect checkpoint function - which is relevant to interpreting the functional consequences of mutations that are seen in cancerous cells. In addition, we have explored experimentally and computationally how concentration changes in the checkpoint target protein Cdc20 (which are observed in some cancers) affect functioning of the checkpoint under physiologic and pathologic conditions. Thus, we now have a better understanding of how proper checkpoint protein concentrations are established and how changes in concentration affect function.

The project has had considerable impact on training the future science and engineering workforce: two graduate students, twelve undergraduate students, and one high school student have enhanced their scientific and professional skills through this project; three came from groups that are strongly underrepresented in the sciences. A group of students from computer science has addressed one of the scientific questions in this project as their capstone projects, and has thereby sharpened their skills in computational sequence analysis. Two interdisciplinary collaborations on this project have strengthened the research network at our university. Furthermore, we have developed image analysis software for the 3D segmentation of cells as part of this project, which is also applicable to research questions in unrelated areas. In addition, the project brought a truly interdisciplinary group of students together (from biology, computer science, music technology, and graphic design) to work on an electronic platform (e.g. for science fairs) that explains gene expression principles by musical analogy. Thus, the project has allowed a large number of students to hone their skills in their chosen area of expertise and to learn how to communicate across disciplines.
